{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3698858,"name":"Josh Targo","username":"joshtargo","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/7bcc69/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-08-02T22:28:46.261Z","cooked":"

We (3494/11329) use Onshape, so some of these skills are specific to that package, but I’m looking for help making this a rational and fairly complete list of skills that students can use as a guide. Hopefully this helps us mentors and the students ensure that CAD training covers the important stuff.

If anyone has edit suggestions or additions, please let me know.

Notion page

Text below:

Onshape Skills Checklist

This checklist outlines the skills expected of student CAD designers using Onshape for FTC and FRC. Progression through the tiers reflects increased responsibility, design complexity, and collaboration. Mastery at Tier 2 is typically sufficient for contributing to robot subsystems; Tiers 3–4 represent leadership and system-level design.

  • Tier 1: Basic Skills – “CAD Ready”

    Create basic parts and small assemblies, and recover from common mistakes.

    Core Skills

    • Navigate Onshape’s UI, tabs, and folders
    • Pan, zoom, and rotate in 3D space
    • Create fully constrained 2D sketches
    • Use basic features to create 3D shapes
    • Understand Mate Connectors
    • Organize and Rename sketches and features
    • Assign material properties and colors

    Basic Assembly

    • Insert parts into assemblies
    • Insert Fasteners from Standard Content
    • Use basic Mates connect parts

    Recovery & Versioning

    • Use undo/redo
    • Use rollback bar to troubleshoot features
    • Understand how to suppress/delete features
    • Understand Workspaces and Versions
    • View and restore earlier history states

  • Tier 2: Intermediate Skills – “Design Contributor”

    Contribute to subsystem designs and start managing their own workspace.

    Part Studio Workflows

    • Model multiple parts in a single Part Studio
    • Derive and modify parts from other studios, documents, and versions
    • Create and edit parts using In-Context references

    Advanced Sketching & Features

    • Use mirror, pattern, project, and offset in sketches
    • Use patterns, split part, and Boolean operations

    Assembly Skills

    • Create, edit, insert, and Mate subassemblies
    • Use Mate Connectors for precise placement
    • Use linear/circular patterns in assemblies
    • Insert and mate COTS parts from MKCad or the FTC Insert Tool
    • Replicate parts
    • Create exploded views for design analysis and robot maintenance

    Recovery & Versioning

    • Create named versions before large changes
    • Revert Main to a named version or timeline point
    • Use version tree to identify when/where errors were introduced

  • Tier 3: Advanced Skills – “Project Lead”

    Manage complete subsystems, and coordinate with other design groups.

    Design Management

    • Create and manage top-level assemblies
    • Use in-context edits and master sketches wisely across documents
    • Organize parts by subsystem and naming conventions

    Motion and Fit

    • Use Mate limits to restrict motion ranges
    • Check for interference and range of motion
    • Save Named Positions

    Documentation

    • Produce 2D drawings with dimensions, callouts, and exploded views
    • Edit part properties using the BOM panel
    • Export parts lists for purchasing or fabrication tracking

    Recovery & Versioning

    • Manage document branching during experimentation or redesign
    • Merge or compare design branches
    • Use workspace versions to document review milestones
    • Identify rollback points for others during peer troubleshooting

  • Tier 4: Expert / Mentor Level – “System Architect”

    Understand and maintain complex systems.

    Automation & Reuse

    • Build reusable templates with variables and configurations
    • Write simple custom features using FeatureScript
    • Manage shared content libraries (MKCad, team gussets, profiles)

    System Integration

    • Create and maintain Master Sketches, Packaging, and Publish Geometry
    • Link subsystems across documents cleanly
    • Design and manage in-context relationships with minimal error risk
    • Drive top-level design decisions based on interdependencies

    Recovery & Versioning

    • Audit entire project timelines for issues
    • Lead version control discipline across the team
    • Diagnose and fix broken references across documents and branches
    • Train others on best practices for branching, merging, and recovery
